So, what to say here?

It's more Survivor Squad. If like myself you enjoyed the original then this holds plenty of promise with the focus on community created content. Fairly barebones right now, a few Gauntlets created by the Dev, two of which are variants on the free Gauntlet DLC for the original game.

To address the elephant in the room: Yes, this is at the core a map editor. Even in this basic state though it seems like a fairly in depth one. If you enjoyed the original game and have a creative streak this will likely be worth your time.

Visually and mechanically the game remains the same as the original, though so far the ability to level your squad is missing. Hopefully that will be added at a later date, either persistent or during each level. The ability to share and download another players idea of hell is something I look forward to.

TL:DR - If you liked Survivor Squad, its a good bet you'll like this too. If you didn't then wait a while longer to see what comes in future updates.

What is Survivor Squad Gauntlet The city/town/outpost has been ravage by zombie apocalypse yet 4 survivor still fight on to reach the escape pad to salvation, will they die or will they become the survivor squad?

And basically that, you have 4 man on a mission to survive and escape a hell-hole and get to the chopper. Along the way you'll have to deal with the occasional mad scientist, crazy cannibalistic flesh eating zombies and special infected. Go me!

Gameplay: Good
So to start with you begin the level with 4 guys armed with nothing more than a pistol to get to the landing pad, Along the way you'll encounter enemies in large numbers swarming to eat your brains although currently the ability to die and heal is not as of yet implemented therefor unless a special manages to grab all 4 of your character you can proceed with the mission in impunity.

There are containers that contains gadgets and weapons that you can find if your team searched them which range from semi auto rifles to full auto ones. Which is really needed since while you cant die [for now] the enemy endlessly pour from in certain section making a faster firing weapon a mandatory thing.

Also in your escape maps called Gauntlets by the way you will encounter modifier within the map such as survival sequences, unlock the door and strangely enough even a puzzle section if you will which makes the game rather adaptable.

Enemies comes in thick and fast in many forms but like in most zombies game they also come in special variety that blinds, smokes, acidify and blow up in the face of your character but as of for now they are mere annoyance rather than actual threat.

You can also specify their viewpoint and tell them to fire that and only in that direction which is needed like 50% of the time but occasionally they still ignore your orders, early access after all.

Essentially it all boils down to get to the chopper game with extra mechanic and story throws in.

If you are a fan of the original then pick this one up as well seeing as it has less bugs and now it has WORKSHOP support therefor there are already a lot of fan made maps on the map list. reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of the original Survivor Squad I was very excited to see Survivor Squad: Gauntlets being released in Early Access.
Gauntlets is essentially a newer, better version of the original Survivor Squad. The gameplay stays true to the original where you have four controllable characters and the aim is to survive by crafting, killing and ultimately staying alive.
The newest standout feature is the ability to create, play and upload your own Gauntlets/Maps. The map creator is somewhat easy to use and not overly time consuming allowing you to create quick and fun maps for you to play and for the community to enjoy also.
The game is in a very barebones state but the potential, as with many Early Access games, is amazing. If you liked the original Survivor Squad then it's almost impossible to go wrong with Gauntlets, but don't expect a full game yet. Currently there are a few good maps made by the developers and a couple made by the community so there is something to do in the game but it's not fleshed out at all yet. Most of the levels are simple and quick to play through but as more people buy the game the levels available will surely increase because as I said before, creating your own gauntlets is not that difficult. There is currently no crafting implemented, or any kind of level structure (I am unsure of the developers plans to add these, I am hoping they do) but there are still new features in the game such as locking your characters to only attack in the direction you've set them to look instead of any in their range which allows you to hold strategic positions better than in the original Survivor Squad, in turn making the game a little more strategy than luck. There is also a new levelling and XP system that allows you to level up as you play through various gauntlets (though as of yet I am not sure where they plan to go with this feature, possibly in the direction of unlocking new weapons/items over time) which is something to look forward to.
If you were a fan of the original Survivor Squad or you enjoy creating levels for games you play then you will 100% enjoy this game, just don't invest yet if you're not willing to wait a while for a game that feels a little more whole. The concept is there and as Endless Loop have proven with the first game, the idea works. I can see this being a very enjoyable game once it's complete and the feedback from the community should help shape this game into something brilliant, but right now the main feature is the map editor which is most likely what you'll spend most, if not all, your time messing around with right now whilst the game is in Alpha.

Have you ever found a diamond in the rough? A game with an amazing concept and execution that it seems nobody has really heard of? That was the original Survivor Squad game for me. The crafting and looking for new survivors while trying to keep your current crew healthy enough to avoid permadeath was fun and engaging. Setting up new bases and balancing your resources between various outposts, and clearing infected zones with your selected survivors offers a glorious mash-up of Left 4 Dead and State of Decay that is absolutely mesmerizing. Survivor Squad Gauntlets is in Early Access, and lacks many of these features, but if these mechanics are combined with the new toys offered in Survivor Squad Gauntlets… It is almost assured to be a game of mammoth proportions.

I absolutely love line-of-sight in games, and this game takes that very seriously. Some maps give you enough light to see movement outside your sight, but most are pitch dark and require extreme caution. A game like Teleglitch offers a wider field of vision, and this is somewhat compensated for by the fact that you have four squad members, but it can take some adjustment (and a few surprise zombie attacks) before you really know how to maneuver them as a unit. If you’re sending four guys into a room to check crates and they have their backs to the door, you may want to think again… Much safer to post someone on guard duty and take a few more seconds to loot the crates than to have uninvited guests. I’ll admit that I enjoyed finding components to craft weapons in the original more than just finding the weapons in this game, but crafting might just make its comeback yet. Picking your fights is also very important, if you’re surrounded by a horde, try to move your squad into a corridor or through a gate so they can all concentrate fire on the same area. Being rewarded for thinking strategically makes this game a real pleasure to play.

The special infected are quite varied, and aside from the Pouncer, Spitter, and Grabber, seem like innovative additions to spice up a game that might otherwise be quite droll. Room to room zombie clearing is one thing… Getting blinded by a smoke cloud and having a couple teammates dragged off makes the whole zombie-clearing thing a bit more complicated. Oh, and you might want to think twice about unleashing that assault rifle, because zombie are like toddlers… They simply LOVE noise. I can’t get enough of the frantic action this game has to offer. Most zombie games have you in first or third person, in the middle of the action, Survivor Squad goes to show that a zombocalypse is a frenetic situation no matter which way you look at it. The puzzles aren’t necessarily difficult to solve, but they do offer a nice chance of pace from breaching, clearing, and searching.  In addition to the addictive strategy, the game also features a level editor so you can create the corpse-filled slaughterhouse of your dreams. You can even edit existing levels to give them a little extra OOMPH! With this feature in place, the replayability is drastically increased, although the build menu could desperately use some music.

I’ve sung the merits of my diamond in the rough, but now I must point out the flaws. The music in the game matches the action, however it is quite forgettable. The voice-acting is just passable, and the voice spam everytime you give an order can be grating, though there is an option to prevent this. The graphics are also nothing to write home about. Some puzzles, if not solved in time, can lead to a complete zombie gangbang. Keeping your members focused in the direction you specify is also quite difficult at the moment, since they spin around to help their allies when they hear gunfire, thus leaving the flank they were assigned to wide open to attack. In addition, the game would greatly benefit from a sneak mode, and the ability to autofire while the squad is performing a move order. Overall, the flaws are easy to overlook because of how enjoyable the game itself is, and just like the original Survivor Squad, I see myself playing this one for a long time to come. There is indeed a bit more polishing to be done for this little beauty, but as it stands I am delighted to see a fantastic indie game like this available for purchase.

Summary: An engaging, but low-budget, top-down strategy game about murdering the undead.

Final Score: 7/10 for gameplay and replayability. 9/10 if original mechanics (crafting/travel) implemented.

In short, it's a fun squad level tactical RTS with a powerful mission (gauntlet) editor, get in, shoot zombies, have fun.

If that's not enough to get you to try the game I'll give you some more Info;
Survivor Squad: Gauntlets is a fun, tactical squad-based RTS Zombie survival experience which focuses on single mission scenarios and a powerful scenario editor tool that ships with the game. The control options for your squad members (up to 4) are simple and fast to learn but hard to master when facing hoards of Zeds, and while you can mow down a lot of them they will overpower you if you fail to place your crew in a good formation as the focus during the missions is pretty much on line-of-sight management and failure to properly space out your crew and let them cover the different possible areas where Zeds might pop up will end with you becoming Zombie fodder.

Besides basic squad movement and tactics the game also features simple (and more complex) puzzle areas that often will reward you with better loot if you manage to pull them off, further boosting your chance to get through the mission.
All of those can be recreated, and further refined on, in the very powerful mission Editor which, as already mentioned, is one of the big selling points of the title; with players being able to share their creations with each other which allowing for a, theoretically, infinity amount of new missions and scenarios.

Some might criticize that there is no progression between missions, nothing to 'level up' but I have to say that I find this rather refreshing as it keeps every mission as a set challenge without the risk to be too powerful or too weak to get through it and it also keeps all those rather annoying 'level up fast' and 'max loot' scenarios from the player created scenario list which make up a large amount in other games featuring community driven content creation.

Now grab it and go shoot dead dudes deader.

I would first like to note that this review comes from a free-key that was provided by the developer in exchange for late beta feedback and/or a promised review and they get both out of me, though the fact that the game was free in no way sways my review.

Though never reviewed by me, I have put many hours into the initial Survival Squad and though it had and still has a few quirky behavioral bugs, for the most part it is a solid game that is well worth playing, but this is not a review of the original, but of the second game: Gauntlets.

Gauntlets uses pretty much the same mechanics as the original game and in it you lead up to 4 characters in a pausable real time zombie fighter but with larger possible maps and a small handful of improvements and fixes over the original, as well as other changes.

Though I realize that likely a majority of readers won't understand the comparison and thus I will explain it after, I would compare this game very much to Jagged Alliance: Deadly Games (which is available at GOG at the time of this review). The original Jagged Alliance (already available on Steam) is an open campaign of a game where the player moves between zones and tries to reach the conclusion of an over-arching in a very free-roam open-world environment, which is sort of what Survivor Squad is. Deadly Games, which was the second game in the series was to Jagged Alliance what Gauntlets is to Survivor Squad. It gives up the openworld, free roam format for a more story driven, level or mission based play style that possesses a much more detailed and linear story than the original, which is also much shorter than the original. The campaign it comes with is 6 missions long and I honestly have yet to finish it, but have played enough that I have a good idea of how it plays out. It's fair enough but in itself not enough that I would actually recommend this game. It would be, as many of my reviews a negative review with a caveat that focuses on a specific niche audience that I recommend try it anyway... Gauntlets is more than just a 6 mission campaign that uses a similar engine though.

Survivor Squad: Gauntlets has is a lot more intricate and has a degree of complexity to what can be done with the engine that the original did not reach, including the ability to have much larger maps to play on.

In addition, Survivor Squad: Gauntlets has an editor that lets players use the engine to craft their own missions and campaigns, giving it a much larger possible scope than the developer produced content it starts with and it is for this reason that I'd tilt my verdict from a negative review to a mildly positive one.

In all, at the less than $10 price point, it's worth a try for anyone that likes the zombie-horror and survival genre, and a must-try for anyone that was a fan of the original Survivor Squad and what it may lack in initial content has great potential to be added to by the community as well as additional content from the developer through additional Gauntlets  (or missions) that can easily be found through the game itself and already consists of enough additional Gauntlets to give it much more potential playtime than the handful of challenging missions it starts with.

Though I wouldn't call it one of the best games I've ever played, I would consider it no less of a waste of money than the original was and is definitely entertaining enough to be worth it's price.

O man this game! If you played the original Survivor Squad, then you already know you will like this!
This is an aboslute amazing spin-off from the original game, hats off to the devs!

The basic premise of the game is quite simple. It's a top down strategic shooter that lets you take control of (up to) four survivors as a squad. Each can be moved and line of sight set independently, or as a whole. The goal? To navigate through a level (or in this case, a Gauntlet) and make it intact and alive to the Heli pad at the end. But this is only the beginning and where it gets real fun!

The idea behind Survivor Squad Gauntlets is that is community based game. That's right, community based. The key feature of the game is a Gauntlet Editor that allows you to make your own levels and share them with the community to play. Likewise, you can play levels that other players have made and that is where the possibilities become Endless! Levels also have a Ranking system so that you can Rank Up or Down levels you like or dislike and see what community favorites are.

The Gauntlet Editor is fairly intuitive and easy to use, and comes with some tutorials to learn the basics of creating levels. It doesn't take long to get the hang of it, and you can create a fairly basic level in a short sitting. If making more involved/larger/epic levels is your cup of tea, your welcome to do that also, with a Saving System so that you can stop where you are, come back hours/days/months later and finish your level. It took me about 3 hrs to get the hang of the Editor, make a level, and get it posted for the Community. Now all that's left is to see how it ranks amongst the players. Early Access Review

DISCLAMER: I was asked by the Developer of this game to test it due to a review I wrote for Doorkickers, which is a mechanically different review. This review is of the Alpha 0.25 and is subject to change.

Survivor Squad: Gauntlets is a Real Time Tactics game where you lead up to 4 survivors through a ♥♥♥♥ ton of zombies. So far I've encountered Spitters (Guys who spit acid coulds), Jumpers (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who jump at survivors and stop them from moving), Grabbers (♥♥♥♥sticks who pull survivors towards them and stop them from moving) and some fat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who take more bullets.

My No.1 problem with the game is that it just feels like it's on autopilot. Compared to Doorkickers (The closest game to this I can think of), this game doesn't really require any planning. Zombies drop like a paid hooker, even with the weakest gun (Gordon). You just move to the helipad, and maybe do a puzzle or two. Nothing really stops you. I respect that the intent of this game is to have the Gauntlets act as 'score attack' levels where players try to get the highest score possible, but beyond that there isn't really much point to replaying a Gauntlet again, and I'd dare say out of the ones I've played so far (Granted, I haven't played all of them) they've all really felt the same.

Problem No.2 is the fact that this game really does seem dependant on users creating content. This isn't a bad way to extend the life of a game, don't get me wrong, but you better hope you can build one hell of a community. I don't know if any items are new from the previous Survivor Squad (as I have not played it) but if no new items, weapons or zombie types have been added, I could see some fans of the original being fairly upset if they have to pay for another game that only really adds an editor.

Graphically this game is pretty bad to be honest. Most things look okay, but the tires look like poorly drawn circles in MS Paint and the character portraits look like cartoons also drawn in MS Paint. A little more focus in this would improve the game a lot. You could also get some mates together and take photos of their face if you want some better portraits. Hell, I'm sure plenty of people would be willing to 'donate' their faces to the game.

Despite all of this, the editor itself is pretty solid to be honest. This isn't exactly a complicated game (in the big picture of things), but the editor is functional, and I've been able to work it out fairly well. It could do with a better tutorial, but to be honest, that's more than games such as Doorkickers and the ARMA series (the only two games  I could think of that have level editors that I play).

The controls do work, apart from reviving downed survivors (which will be fixed). Controls are pretty simple, and don't take too long to get use to.

All in all, this game has potential, but in it's current state, it's not very challenging nor does it demand any strategical thinking from the player.The graphics are too simpilistic and the devs are leaning too much on the content created by the players. At the same time, I will state that most games in early Alpha probably have this level of polish (especially indie games) so am optimistic that this game will improve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survivor Squad: Gauntlets is a squad management zombie survival game with a top down PoV and a focus on the line-of-sight mechanic.

You have control over a group of survivors, as a whole and independently from each other, and have to micromanage these aspects of control in order to complete each gauntlet or mission. You will need to tactically plan ahead of every movement you make or you'll end up suffering the consequences of poor foresight, which often include having your arm chewed on by an undead.

But what control does Survivor Squad: Gauntlets give us in order to avoid such a fate? Well, firstly there's movement, you will need to move and you will need to do it in different ways according to each situation you encounter. Maybe you want to make a run for an exit and risk gathering a horde behind you... Or maybe you'd prefer to be safe and sound and walk, guns held tight and ready? Maybe you want to send each survivor in a direction to collect supplies and save time, because you never know what can happen as the night progresses... Or you'd prefer to keep it tight and take your time? Whatever you decide, you will need to get a move on sooner or later, so you better think well where you're going.

Another mechanic you'll need to master to achieve success, and one the game puts a special emphasis on, is the Line of Sight. Your survivors can't shoot at what they can't see, much like in real life. Line of Sight interacts with your surroundings as well, including getting narrower vision if you're in a small alley, or being able to see through a crack in the wall or a window, or even security cameras if you can access them! Remember that your survivors can act independently and as a group, and if one of them sees something the rest of the team will notice too, so take advantage of this and make each of them cover as much ground as possible to avoid any sneaky zed from suprising you. If you want, you can also make them focus on their line of sight only and to ignore the calls of the others, really useful if you're caught in a horde in a place with more than one entrance and need all the entrances to be covered at all times.

Of course, what would a zombie game be without guns? So far I've encountered pistols, shotguns, rifles, flamethrowers and even grenade launchers. Each one has its own stats and each one is useful in different situations, for example, a grenade launcher might be ideal if you're entrenched in a building and covering an entrance, but it might not be the best thing to carry if you're in the open or in a tight building.

Then there's items. As you progress through a gauntlet you may find a variety of items that could be of use in your mission. Ranging from videocameras to teleporters, passing through autoturrets and sonars and a myriad more, you will find a use for every single one in multiple situations: Need to hold of an horde whilst waiting for an evac? An autoturret will mow down the incoming zeds in a hail of bullets. Collecting supplies and need to drop them off at your transport? Teleport away and avoid walking in the open and risking getting caught by a random horde (just make sure you don't run out of energy for it!).

And then there's what I'll admit are my absolute favorite parts of each gauntlet: the interactivity and the situations. Normally you will have a more or less specific objective to accomplish, but the game lets you decide how to fullfil it. Apart from that, the map is full of little curios that you can interact with (or not) to achieve a certain outcome. Each one is different and sometimes you won't be sure of the outcome, but you might want to risk it anyway, who knows? Maybe it'll open a secret path, an armory or a shortcut if you press  that  button... Or it might trigger an alarm, a bomb or who knows what! The situations are also great, this game achieves an atmosphere of uncertainty that really gives it a special charm and that I think more games of the zombie genre should strive to achieve. You can never be sure of anything, you might think you have everything planned beforehand and start walking, but who knows if a random horde will trigger that you didn't prepare yourself for? Or the way might be blocked without you knowing, or there might be a bomb in a building that you just entered and will have to risk your life disabling it, or let it take the building and whatever valuables might be inside, and lose a potential stronghold for later on in the process. This interactivity combined with variety of situations and feeling of uncertainty works really well in Survivor Squad: Gauntlets. Other games with similar mechanics (squad management) often become a bit stale because you basically just click and wait, click and wait, click and wait because everything is easy to plan for and there's nothing to put you under stress or make you react; in Survivor Squad: Gauntlets you certainly click, but I wouldn't wait if I were you, better keep an eye up because anything can happen... and will probably happen.

On a more technical note, there's the graphics and sound. No, it's no Crysis, but it's got a nice style going on and it looks good to the eye and sounds good to the ear, what else can you ask for? The style works well with the game and the main non-gameplay feature (the gauntlets), where a more cumbersome style might cluster your vision too much, but Survivor Squad: Gauntlets manages to find a nice equilibrium. The sound is good too, not spectacular, but good enough. On a note, but reiterating that it IS in fact still Early Access, the music is not too varied and can get repetitive to listen to the same tracks over and over, if the developers are planning on adding more tracks, then all the better, and if not you can always disable the ingame music and play a custom playlist of yours for a more personalized experience.

Lastly, and what I think sells the game better than anything, is, as the title of the game would suggest to you, the gauntlets.  These are the scenenarios on which you play each time. The developers have made quite a bit of them that act as a story, but what's really awesome is that you can create custom ones and share them or play in gauntlets made by other players like you! This feature is awesome and ensures that you can always pop up the game and have a new experience even if you have wore out the rest of features the game has to offer.

All in all I really, really, really recommend this game to everybody regardless of their preferred genre, even if you haven't played a squad management game the tutorial and first missions will teach you fast enough so that in ten minutes you can work your way around the game intuitively. And if you've played them, then you will love this one.

So grab your shotty and remember, leave no man behind!

survivor squad: gauntlets is, simply put, survivor squad + improvements, and most of what i have to say about survivor squad has already been said in my review of the first game. but rather than talking about the first game, lets go into what this game has done to improve and change what survivor squad has already established.

first off, a rather minor thing at best, is the charactors and voice acting, its generally better here, but it is, again, a minor detail.

the aiming machanic is greatly improved (or something i hadn't noticed in the first game due to lack of tutorial*). aiming in this game works better here due to 2 good features, locking aiming direction and moving while looking a specific direction. these 2 abilities allow you to better secure areas and check corners. good things to have in squad based game play.

the inventory system as been reworked a bit, but i hardly noticed due to not having to pick up everything i needed like in the first game.

where the first game was procedural generated, gauntlets allows for user created maps, and knowing how creating some users can be, great things can come from it. but this comes with a slight downside, there was only a few non user created maps (last time i played), meaning that most levels have to be user created. but then again, the map editor is built in, so, get bored, build your own level. simple...

other than that, i've run out of things to say about the game in the rather short time i've played it, it was as simple as the first game and in the end, it felt almost the same in most aspects

*another improvement the devs added was the inclusion of a basic tutorial for basic controls, whereas the first game has a brief opening sceen that allows you to move, nothing more

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nNot only is this game a great RTS Survival game (especially for a fast paced game set in the zombie apocalypse), but it also has one of the best, if not THE best level editor I've ever used! I absolutely recommend this game, it shows just how fleshed out you can make a level editor and it properly communicates how to use it despite being very complex.
